title: Mass to Moles
description: Calculate moles from mass and molar mass

examples.problem: Calculate the number of moles in 25.0 g of CaCO₃ (molar mass = 100.1 g/mol).

study_tips.concept: The mole is the fundamental unit for measuring amounts of substances in chemistry. This calculation converts mass (what you can weigh) to moles (what participates in reactions).
key_points: Always use the correct molar mass from the periodic table
Check units: mass in grams, molar mass in g/mol, result in mol
The mole ratio determines stoichiometric relationships in reactions
vce_connections: Unit 1 AoS 2: Foundation for all stoichiometric calculations
Unit 3 AoS 1: Essential for solution preparation and analysis
Unit 4 AoS 1: Used in equilibrium and acid-base calculations
common_errors: Using atomic mass instead of molar mass for compounds
Forgetting to convert between g and kg when needed
Confusing mass with weight (mass is constant, weight varies)
extensions: How would you calculate moles if given the volume and density?
What's the relationship between moles and Avogadro's number?
How does this calculation connect to chemical equation balancing?

interactive_questions.question: How many moles are present in 58.4 g of sodium chloride (NaCl)? The molar mass of NaCl is 58.4 g/mol.
interactive_questions.follow_up: Perfect! This represents exactly one mole of NaCl, which contains 6.022 × 10²³ formula units.

interactive_questions.question: A student has 12.5 g of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃). If the molar mass is 100.1 g/mol, how many moles is this?
interactive_questions.follow_up: This is exactly 1/8 of a mole. In stoichiometry problems, you'll often work with fractional moles like this.
